## {background-image="Images/11_2-scimyst_dustbowl.webp" .center}

::: notes

The Dust Bowl is a perfect storm of misery

- Happens during the great depression so the economics of the time were already awful

- It goes way longer than many realized (10+ years)

- That 10 years was marked by serious drought conditions, excessive heat and frequent dust storms

- The dust storms blew at 60+ miles per hour and lasted anywhere from 1 hour to 3.5 days in length

- The dust was carried all the way to Boston and was reported by ships 300 miles into the Atlantic ocean

<br>

I find the scale of this ecological disaster hard to grasp.

- Dust storms so massive and disruptive as to drive dust particles across the continent and way out to sea.

<br>

**SLIDE**: For today we need to examine why this happened and whether it is likely to happen again!

:::

## Chapter 5: Key Ideas {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center}

- American culture defined by capitalistic ethos.

- Capitalism attaches us to cash, not the earth.

- Capitalism teaches us our survival is separate from nature's survival (autonomy and indifference).

- Capitalism views all resources commercially and imperially.

::: notes

*Notes to Hit*

**According to Worster in chapter 5, what specific effects did introducing "machines" onto the plains have?**

- **e.g. tractors, plows, threshers and the combine**

- Do the work of 10-20 men without having to deal with those seasonal harvest laborers
    
    - p88 land entries skyrocket

    - p90 Labor needs fall AND acreage planted jumps!

    - p91 transforms you from clod to operator! From dumb brute to mechanic!
    
<br>

**Who were the "suitcase farmers"? (p93)**

- Machines made it easier to farm, this encouraged more people to do it. 

- Part-time farmers: Come in from town for planting and then leave until harvest time in the hopes something good grows.

<br>

**How does Worster use these "suitcase farmers" to make his argument?**

- (Capitalism + Technology = Suitcase farmers)

- (Suitcase farmers never develop a meaningful connection to the land.)

- (No connection to land -> abuse -> catastrophe)

<br>

In short, why does Worster argue the sodbusters failed where the indians succeeded?

- (Sodbusters focused on farming to maximize resource extraction from the land.)

- Early attempts failed when subjected to dust storms and long droughts.

## Worster's (1979) Argument {background-image="Images/background-forest_v3.png" .center .smaller}

<br>

- American culture is capitalist

- Capitalism replaces our national identity with one focused on being an isolated, economically stressed individual (consumer)

- Capitalism teaches us that nature is a resource and our survival is separate from nature's survival

- Capitalism shortens time horizons and creates incentives to ignore science

**Therefore, capitalism caused the Dust Bowl**

::: notes
